title: Knee Consultation - Discoid Meniscus Evaluation
summary: Patient consultation for knee issue. Doctor diagnosed likely discoid meniscus with delamination based on patient presentation. Recommended arthroscopic surgery to remove torn portion and reshape meniscus. Patient already scheduled with another doctor for the 26th but considering this surgeon as well. 90% chance of substantial improvement with surgery, 4-6 weeks recovery, can walk immediately after if excision performed.

reason_for_visit.description: Patient experiencing knee issues, likely related to meniscus tear

details.title: Likely Discoid Meniscus with Delamination
details.description: Patient appears to have a discoid meniscus (abnormal shape where meniscus is disc-like or dish-shaped instead of having normal curved shape) that has delaminated. The tears are generally not repairable and appear crab-like in pattern. However, doctor noted that sometimes upon arthroscopy, tears may be found to be repairable.

todos.title: Arthroscopic Knee Surgery
todos.description: Arthroscopy involves making three small incisions in the knee. The procedure will remove the torn portion of the meniscus and reshape it to normal appearance while preserving as much healthy meniscus tissue as possible. If tissue is found to be repairable during surgery, doctor will opt for repair instead. Repair would require crutches and brace for 6 weeks when out of bed. If excision only, can walk immediately with no crutches needed. Recovery takes 4-6 weeks. 90% chance of substantial improvement, 1% chance of making it worse. Risks include infection, blood clot, or anesthetic complication. Surgery typically scheduled 3-4 weeks out. Performed at two locations: one near Pennsylvania parking area, another in a different band location.

follow_up.description: Review arthroscopic findings and show patient what the meniscus looked like during the procedure

learnings.title: Discoid Meniscus
learnings.description: A discoid meniscus is a congenital condition where instead of having a normal carved-out crescent shape, the meniscus is more disc-like or dish-shaped with less carve-out. More meniscus tissue without the normal shape creates higher chance of delamination (tearing in layers).

learnings.title: Meniscus Repair vs Excision
learnings.description: Repair means suturing the tissue back together to heal. Excision means removing a portion of the torn meniscus and reshaping the remaining portion to look like a normal meniscus. Doctor is aggressive with repairs when possible because the tissue is valuable for protecting cartilage, especially in younger patients.

learnings.title: Meniscus Function
learnings.description: The cartilage needs a certain amount of protection from the meniscus to be maintained and protected. It is unclear exactly how much meniscus can be lost before deterioration begins, but it is suspected to be a small amount. This is why surgeons try to remove the least amount necessary.

learnings.title: Anesthesia for Procedure
learnings.description: Procedure typically uses light general anesthesia with nerve block to reduce post-operative pain. Propofol is commonly used as it puts patients out without causing nausea and allows for alert awakening with very little downside. Allows surgeon to manipulate the knee fully during procedure.

learnings.title: Post-Excision Outcome
learnings.description: Sometimes patients with discoid meniscus have an overabundance of meniscus tissue, so after excision and reshaping, they end up with what looks like a normal meniscus and have not lost anything compared to a normal person.
